awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project is a game-based learning virtual reality (VR) and desktop experience focused on fostering STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) and robotics interest in young people. The project's intent is to address the growing skilled labor shortage in STEM fields and prepare learners for the cross-industrial rise of robotics. Through exposure to experiential STEM learning, the project will create a groundswell of student interest and aptitude that will help close STEM workforce gaps in the long term, as well as plant the seeds for a future cohort of robotics professionals. The project's hypothesis is that its game-based VR-enhanced learning platform can reliably instill design/engineering thinking skills into learners while exceeding the capabilities of existing educational tools in terms of scalability and adaptability to student needs. The project is additionally intended to drive K-12 VR hardware adoption by providing a compelling and teacher-customizable solution that will justify institutional hardware investments. When proven scalable, the project will act as a beachhead for other VR and game-based learning entrants to bring their own innovative learning content into the K-12 ecosystem, simultaneously promoting the progress of science in alignment with the NSF's mission, as well as providing a broad economic lift to the American economy by unlocking a new market sector. 

As a VR-first experience, this project will provide students with a first-of-its-kind immersive robotics sandbox that allows for hands-on experimentation. Players will be able to form hypotheses, build robots, test, and iterate, mirroring the processes of project-based robotics and maker programs. Beyond robot construction, the project will offer challenge courses that test players' ability to build to specification. Each course will require a different physics-based solution for which a capable robot must be constructed. For example, a course might challenge players to navigate a set of stationary obstacles and then place a cube on a pressure plate, requiring a robot with maneuverability and the ability to pick up, transport, and place objects. This task serves as a model of the underlying dynamics of engineering design: identifying a problem, thinking critically, and developing a solution engineered specifically to that problem. To establish this project in the larger context of teaching media, it will be developed as a desktop-only intervention, a VR-only intervention, a desktop/VR hybrid intervention, and a paper-based control intervention. These variants will be tested with middle school and high school end users to verify the efficacy of game-based VR as a pedagogy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Our Phase II funding was used to investigate whether a digital robotics solution can increase students' interest and sense of efficacy in STEM disciplines at a fraction of the cost of physical robotics programs. We developed a digital robotics game named RoboCo, with both a desktop and touch VR version, in order to investigate whether hands-on VR experiences have unique positive effects (compared to desktop-only experiences) on student dispositions toward STEM. By creating an affordable, digital robotics kit analog that's easy to implement, we equipped ourselves to investigate whether a digital solution can spread robotics to a larger audience of learners than is currently being served by traditional solutions. 

For the Phase II pilot study, twelve teachers and their students used RoboCo, either through a PC desktop version or through streaming access, for a minimum of five weeks (7.5 hours). Research firm WestEd collected data on the short-term impacts of RoboCo on students' engineering understanding, 21st century problem solving, and attitudes towards STEM, as well as feedback on the usability, feasibility, and perceptions of value in using RoboCo for learning robotics. VR was not evaluated during this study due to pandemic-related hygiene complications.

Teachers' estimates of their students' 21st century skills varied at the study outset. Consistent with changes in students' understanding, these estimates improved for three standards-based skills related to problem solving and analysis after using RoboCo. Eight out of 12 teachers reported improvement in students' ability to "elaborate, refine, analyze, and evaluate their own ideas in order to improve and maximize creative efforts" and to "analyze how parts of a whole interact with each other to produce overall outcomes in complex systems," and 9 of 12 teachers recorded improvement in students' ability to "effectively solve different kinds of non-familiar problems in both conventional and innovative ways." Students expressed increased positivity, after using RoboCo, towards questions about their interest in STEM education and the perceived value of science education. WestEd observed the greatest changes in students' responses to the items related to the utility of engineering for everyday life and interest in a career in science. Students responded more positively towards survey items about their interest in engineering and related activities after using RoboCo. These changes were greatest for students' responses to items related to interest in creating new products and interest in what makes machines work. 

Our Phase IIB match on external funding from FIRST was used to expand and enrich RoboCo's robotics-oriented pedagogy features. These funds were used to develop a game-wide time and budget system which facilitates additional engineering constraints and a deeper scoring system. With this system we enabled the game to assess the player's robot designs in terms of expediency, affordability, and utility/effectiveness. We also worked with our new collaborators at FIRST to identify objectives which would support expanded mechanical engineering learning, provide more robust feedback, and create better alignment with FIRST Robotics' real-world competitions. These features were generated with FIRST with the goal of creating a foundation for the use of RoboCo as a platform for FIRST competitions. Our goals were to add additional parts (e.g. torsion springs) to the game; add additional challenges and objectives to the game, including challenges based on real-world scenarios and objectives that explicitly require programming; add sensor readouts and data visualization overlays; refine the tutorial and add additional onboarding and scaffolding; add additional post-challenge reports; and add a robot design iteration log to prompt players to reflect on the strengths and weaknesses of each robot prototype and perform the engineering design process.

Research results from Phase IIB were gathered from an informal survey regarding our inaugural implementation of RoboCo as a platform for competitive robotics; specifically, the 2021 FIRST Global RoboCo Challenge (FGRC21). FGRC21 was an Olympics-style, international robotics competition that took place digitally in RoboCo in collaboration with FIRST Global. Running from 1 November to 18 December 2021, the Challenge tasked participants with playing RoboCo on their computers, capturing their best attempts at each round. At the conclusion of this competition, a survey was sent out to all participants, from which we received 21 adult team member responses and 48 student team member responses. Responses were highly promising with regard to the cultivation of 21st century skills that remain central to our intended pedagogical outcomes. When asked about RoboCo's impact in the areas of collaboration, creativity, STEM engagement, and STEM understanding, respondents were overwhelmingly positive, with almost no negative feedback.

Thanks to the NSF SBIR program, we are well-positioned for commercial success on our target 11/3/22 launch date. RoboCo is a mature, well-groomed example of game-based learning efficacy for digital robotics learning, and the quality and vision of the design has also allowed us to secure deals with Meta and Roblox to bring versions of RoboCo to their platforms in 2023.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2022
Modified by: Daniel N White
